On Tue, 15 Jun 2004 14:16:40 +0100, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> At 23:15 02/06/2004, you wrote:
> > >So I could be sold that "junk DNA" might be useful, perhaps extremely
> > >so.  But the idea of a lot of neutral or slightly maladaptive
> > >structure expressed in the phenotype, that is just waiting around to
> > >become useful?  I'm *highly* skeptical that this is a good idea.
> 
> Sorry, lost track of who said this but:

That was me.

> In cells, one advantage of junk DNA is the way the indirect encoding operates.
> 
> DNA codes proteins... and proteins are simply dropped into the cytoplasm
> (or the membrane, or one of a small number of other places).
> 
> So, a non-functional mutated copy of a gene in the junk DNA can be
> activated, and then very easily plugs into the existing systems.  e.g. the
> protein is created, dropped into the cytoplasm, and is then immediately
> playing a role in the cells control systems.  

Well, you're describing something that, when expressed in the
*phenotype* becomes beneficial.

My point, which I think still holds up reasonably well, is that
organisms don't do very well when they have a lot of neutral or
maladaptive structure in their phenotype.

Derek
